Downshifting while going too fast may cause the motorcycle to lurch and the rear wheel to skid. When riding downhill or shifting into first gear, you may need to use the brakes to slow to a safe speed before downshifting.

questions.question: When riding near stopped or slow-moving cars, a motorcyclist should:
questions.answerA: Pull over and wait until traffic begins to move.
questions.answerB: Ride on the shoulder to get through the area as quickly as possible.
questions.answerC: Weave between the cars to get through the area as quickly as possible.
questions.answerD: Not weave between the cars.
questions.explanation: Riding between slowed or parked cars can leave you vulnerable to unexpected hazards, such as opening car doors or cars suddenly pulling into traffic. If a hazard arises, you will not have room to safely maneuver. Never travel on the shoulder of a road because other drivers will never expect you to be there.

questions.question: Before riding, check all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: The amount of tread on your tires.
questions.answerC: The reflective quality of your tires.
questions.answerD: The general condition of the sidewalls on your tires.
questions.explanation: Before every ride, be sure to check your tires' inflation pressure, your tires' treadwear, and the general condition of the sidewalls and tread surface on the tires.

questions.question: If your motorcycle starts to wobble, you should:
questions.answerC: Grip the handlebars firmly and close the throttle gradually.
questions.answerD: Downshift.
questions.explanation: Do not try to accelerate out of a wobble because doing so will only make the motorcycle more unstable. Instead, grip the handlebars firmly, slow down by gradually closing the throttle, move your weight as far forward and downward as possible, and pull off the road as soon as you can. Avoid applying the brakes, as this may also worsen the wobble.

questions.question: When selecting a helmet, make sure it is all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Designed to meet U.S. Department of Transportation standards.
questions.answerC: Defect-free.
questions.answerD: Attractive.
questions.explanation: You should select a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation and state standards; fits snugly all the way around; and has no obvious defects, such as cracks, loose padding, or frayed straps.

questions.question: When in traffic, motorcycles need:
questions.answerA: Much less distance to stop than cars.
questions.answerB: Less distance to stop than cars.
questions.answerC: As much distance to stop as cars.
questions.answerD: More distance to stop than cars.
questions.explanation: In traffic, a motorcycle needs as much distance to stop as a car does.

questions.question: If you are hit by a wind blast caused by a passing vehicle, you will have the most room for error if you are riding:
questions.answerA: In the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: In the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: In the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: On the shoulder.
questions.explanation: If you are in the middle portion of your lane, you will have the greatest room for error if your control is disrupted by a wind blast from a passing vehicle.

questions.question: More than half of all crashes:
questions.answerA: Occur at speeds greater than 35 mph.
questions.answerC: Are caused by worn tires.
questions.answerD: Involve riders who have ridden their motorcycles for less than six months.
questions.explanation: Always take extra care when riding a new or unfamiliar motorcycle. Most crashes involve riders who have had less than six months of experience with the motorcycle that they are using.

questions.question: When both braking and swerving must be done to avoid an unexpected hazard, a rider should:
questions.answerA: Perform one action, then the other.
questions.answerB: Perform both actions at the same time and apply extra braking pressure.
questions.answerC: Perform both actions at the same time, but mainly focus on swerving.
questions.answerD: Not perform either action.
questions.explanation: Because you need adequate traction to swerve safely, you should not brake and swerve at the same time. Instead, if you approach a hazard that requires you to brake and swerve, you should perform one action and then the other.

questions.question: When riding under ideal conditions, you should maintain a minimum following distance of:
questions.answerC: Three seconds.
questions.answerD: Four seconds.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, you should maintain a following distance of at least two seconds. Increase your following distance any time conditions are less than perfect.

questions.question: The best lane position:
questions.answerA: Is always the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Is always the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Is always the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Varies based on road, weather, and traffic conditions.
questions.explanation: There is no single lane position that is always best and no single lane position that should always be avoided. You should vary your lane position in response to changes in riding conditions.

questions.question: A flat front tire is especially hazardous because:
questions.answerB: The front tire provides the power for the bike, so you will lose acceleration.
questions.answerC: The flat tire will shake the bike, making it hard to use the mirrors.
questions.answerD: You won’t be able to use the brake.
questions.explanation: A flat front tire is especially dangerous because it affects your ability to steer. If your front tire goes flat while you are riding, safely exit the road as quickly as possible.

questions.question: Since most crashes happen during daylight hours, you should:
questions.answerB: Wear bright clothing all the time.
questions.answerC: Ride on the shoulder and stay out of traffic.
questions.answerD: Wear dark clothing all the time.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes happen in broad daylight. You should always wear brightly-colored clothing when riding to maximize your chances of being seen, even during the day.

questions.question: Which of the following does not offer protection to a motorcycle rider?
questions.answerB: Boots that go over the ankle
questions.answerC: A baseball cap that fits snugly
questions.answerD: Gloves
questions.explanation: To protect yourself against injury, you should wear a DOT-compliant helmet; face or eye protection; a jacket and long pants made of sturdy material; boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles; and gloves made of durable material.

questions.question: Which type of sign is yellow with black lettering or symbols?
questions.answerC: Regulatory
questions.answerD: Speed limit
questions.explanation: Warning signs are yellow with black lettering or symbols and provide important information to motorists about upcoming road conditions.

questions.question: An experienced rider:
questions.answerA: Changes positions within their lane as conditions change.
questions.answerB: Stays in one portion of a lane at all times.
questions.answerC: Weaves within the lane to be more visible.
questions.answerD: Travels only on the oily portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: Unlike drivers of larger vehicles, a motorcyclist has three lane position options in their travel lane. The rider should select whichever position is safest based on road and traffic conditions.

questions.question: To reduce your reaction time, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride slower than the speed limit.
questions.answerB: Cover the clutch and the brakes.
questions.answerC: Shift into neutral when slowing.
questions.answerD: Pull in the clutch when turning.
questions.explanation: To help reduce your reaction time, you should cover the clutch and brakes. This is especially helpful when riding through areas where potential hazards are likely.

questions.question: If the chain or belt of your motorcycle breaks, you will:
questions.answerA: Experience a sudden increase in power to the rear wheel.
questions.answerB: Experience a sudden loss of power to the rear wheel.
questions.answerC: Experience a sudden loss of power to the front wheel.
questions.answerD: Experience a sudden increase in power to the front wheel.
questions.explanation: If your drive chain or belt fails, you will experience an immediate loss of power to the rear wheel.

questions.question: When riding in a group while passing another vehicle, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Allow one rider to fully pass the other vehicle before another rider begins to pass.
questions.answerB: Allow several members of the group to pass the other vehicle at once.
questions.answerC: Have the last rider in the group wave to the driver being passed to signal that no other motorcycles are approaching.
questions.answerD: Pass in a staggered formation.
questions.explanation: Riders in a group should overtake another vehicle one at a time. Each rider should complete their pass and resume their position in the group formation before the next rider begins to pass.

questions.question: Smoothly downshifting on motorcycles:
questions.answerB: Can allow the rider to engine brake.
questions.answerC: Is illegal.
questions.answerD: Should not be done if other vehicles are around.
questions.explanation: Engine braking by smoothly downshifting can be a useful option for motorcyclists. If you choose to engine brake, apply your brake lights separately to let other drivers know that you are slowing down.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume the motorcycle is as easy to see as other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Assume other drivers can’t see you.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned with taking steps to ensure that other drivers see you.
questions.answerD: Ride offensively.
questions.explanation: Because motorcycles are small in stature and have fewer and smaller lights than other vehicles, they can be difficult to see. For your safety, it is best to ride defensively and assume that others on the road do not see you.

questions.question: Which factor does not play a role in a person’s blood alcohol content (BAC)?
questions.answerC: How quickly the alcohol was consumed
questions.answerD: How often alcohol is consumed
questions.explanation: The three major factors that impact a person's blood alcohol content are the amount of alcohol they have consumed, how quickly they have consumed it, and their body weight. The person's sex, physical condition, and food intake may also have some effect.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Is not necessary if you have a windshield.
questions.answerC: Protects more than just your eyes.
questions.answerD: Does not protect your face as well as goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield helps protect your entire face, including your eyes. Goggles can protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for either.

questions.question: When braking, you should use:
questions.answerC: Both front and rear brakes.
questions.answerD: Either the front or rear brake, but not both.
questions.explanation: You should always use both brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: Of the crashes involving both a motorcycle and a car, how many are caused by the driver failing to properly yield the right-of-way to the rider?
questions.answerC: Over 50 percent
questions.answerD: About 90 percent
questions.explanation: Of the crashes involving both a motorcycle and a car, more than half are caused by the driver failing to properly yield right-of-way to the rider.

questions.question: When you are being passed by another vehicle, which part of the lane should you ride in?
questions.answerC: The right
questions.answerD: It doesn’t matter.
questions.explanation: When being passed, it is generally safest to ride in the center portion of your lane. Riding on the side nearest the passing vehicle increases the risk of colliding with them. Riding on the side farthest from the passing vehicle is also dangerous, as it could tempt the driver to re-enter your lane before it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Which of the following will protect your eyes from the wind?
questions.answerC: Sunglasses
questions.answerD: Eyeglasses
questions.explanation: Goggles and face shields can protect a rider's eyes from the wind. Windshields, eyeglasses, and sunglasses generally do not shield a rider's eyes adequately enough.

questions.question: When riding in fog, you should:
questions.answerC: Use no lights.
questions.answerD: Alternate between the low and high beams.
questions.explanation: You should use your low beam headlight when riding in foggy conditions. Do not use your high beams when riding near other vehicles.

questions.question: Under normal conditions, a motorcycle operator should maintain a following distance of at least:
questions.answerC: Three seconds.
questions.answerD: Four seconds.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, it is recommended that a motorcyclist maintains a following distance of at least two seconds. They should increase their following distance any time road or traffic conditions are less than perfect.

questions.question: When preparing to pass another vehicle on the left, you should ride in:
questions.answerA: The left side of the lane.
questions.answerC: The right side of the lane.
questions.answerD: Either the right or center portions of the lane.
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass another vehicle on the left, you should ride in the left portion of your lane. This lane position will provide you with the most effective view of the passing lane.

questions.question: Impairment from alcohol:
questions.answerB: Begins at about half of the legal limit.
questions.answerC: Occurs at the legal limit.
questions.answerD: Occurs only if you have had multiple drinks.
questions.explanation: As little as one drink can have a significant effect on the abilities that you need for safe riding. You can be impaired even if you are well below the legal blood alcohol limit. No amount of alcohol is safe to consume before riding.

questions.question: Who should set the pace in a group of riders?
questions.answerB: The riders just behind the leader
questions.answerC: The rider in back
questions.answerD: The oldest rider
questions.explanation: The last rider in a group of motorcyclists should set the pace of travel. Having the last rider set the pace will ensure that no riders are left behind.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a possible cause of a wobble on your motorcycle?
questions.answerC: Unsuitable accessories
questions.answerD: Uneven road
questions.explanation: Most wobbles can be traced to improper loading, unsuitable accessories, or incorrect tire pressure. Do not try to accelerate out of a wobble.

questions.question: Which of the following should you inspect during a pre-ride check?
questions.answerA: The general wear and tread of your tires
questions.answerB: The amount of cushion your seat has
questions.answerC: The shine of your paint
questions.answerD: The wind direction
questions.explanation: Before setting off on any ride, you should do a thorough check of your motorcycle. Inspect the tires, oil and fluid levels, headlight, tail light, turn signals, brake light, clutch and throttle, mirrors, brakes, and horn.

questions.question: When riding in rain or fog, you should:
questions.answerC: Not use your headlight.
questions.answerD: Alternate between your headlight's low and high beam settings.
questions.explanation: You should use your low beam headlight when riding in snowy, rainy, or foggy weather. A high beam headlight can reflect off of these conditions and make it more difficult for a rider to see.

questions.question: When deciding on a lane position, you should:
questions.answerA: Always ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Always ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Always ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Be flexible and base your decision off of numerous factors.
questions.explanation: In general, there is no single best lane position. No portion of the lane need be avoided at all times. Position yourself in the portion of the lane where you are most likely to be seen and you can maintain a cushion of space around you.

questions.question: When being passed from behind, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Stay in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Move onto the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Activate your turn signal.
questions.explanation: When you are being passed from behind or by an oncoming vehicle, stay in the center portion of your lane. Riding any closer to the passing vehicle can put you in danger.

questions.question: When looking for a protective jacket or pair of pants, you should look for:
questions.answerC: Items made of light materials.
questions.answerD: Items that are darkly-colored.
questions.explanation: It is safest to wear long pants and a jacket to fully cover your arms and legs while riding. Clothing made of leather can provide the highest level of protection.

questions.question: A child passenger:
questions.answerA: Should be placed in front of the operator.
questions.answerB: Should be placed behind the operator.
questions.answerC: Does not have to be able to reach the footrests.
questions.answerD: Should hold onto the motorcycle frame.
questions.explanation: A child passenger on a motorcycle should always ride immediately behind the operator. A child sitting in front may be unable to balance properly and could interfere with the operator's use of the controls.

questions.question: When riding in a group, it is best to put inexperienced riders near the front because:
questions.answerA: Experienced riders can more easily keep an eye on them.
questions.answerB: They will get lost if they are leading.
questions.answerC: They may slow the group down as the leaders.
questions.answerD: They will ride too fast in any other position.
questions.explanation: In a group, less experienced riders should ride toward the front, just behind the leader, so more experienced riders can easily watch them.

questions.question: To control your motorcycle well, you should:
questions.answerA: Sit with your arms propping you up rather than steering.
questions.answerB: Keep your knees against the gas tank for balance.
questions.answerC: Allow your feet to hang off the footrests.
questions.answerD: Sit so far back that you must stretch to reach the handgrips.
questions.explanation: When riding, keep your knees against the gas tank to help maintain your balance in turns. Sit so that you can use your arms to steer rather than to prop yourself up. Sit far enough forward that your arms are slightly bent when you hold the handgrips, and keep your feet firmly on the footrests.

questions.question: ______ is a guarantee that another driver sees you.
questions.answerC: Following another vehicle
questions.answerD: Nothing
questions.explanation: Nothing guarantees that a driver sees you. It is safest to assume that if another vehicle can enter your path, it will.

questions.question: Handlebars may be:
questions.answerA: No more than four inches above the seat.
questions.answerB: No more than 10 inches above the seat.
questions.answerC: No more than 15 inches above the seat.
questions.answerD: No more than 25 inches above the seat.
questions.explanation: In Vermont, the handgrips of a motorcycle's handlebars may be no more than 15 inches above the seat.

questions.question: Each traffic lane gives the motorcyclist how many paths of travel?
questions.answerC: Three
questions.answerD: Four
questions.explanation: Each traffic lane provides three paths of travel for motorcyclists: the left, center, and right portions of the lane.

questions.question: To lean the motorcycle for a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Press the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerB: Press the handgrip in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.answerC: Apply the front brake.
questions.answerD: Apply the rear brake.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle needs to lean in order to turn. To make this happen, press on the handgrip in the direction you want to turn.

questions.question: If you must brake and swerve to avoid a hazard, you should:
questions.answerA: Either brake then swerve or swerve then brake.
questions.answerB: Brake and swerve at the same time.
questions.answerC: Choose to either brake or swerve.
questions.answerD: Not swerve and only use the front brake to stop.
questions.explanation: If a hazard requires you to brake and swerve to avoid a collision, you should take the actions separately. Do not brake while swerving because doing so may cause your motorcycle to fall over.

questions.question: When checking tires before a ride, you should look at all of the following except:
questions.answerC: General tread
questions.answerD: Shininess
questions.explanation: Before each ride, you should check the air pressure, tread, and general wear of your tires.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should position themselves:
questions.answerA: In the front of the group.
questions.answerC: Close to the back of the group.
questions.answerD: At the tail end of the group.
questions.explanation: In a group of motorcyclists, less experienced riders should be positioned toward the front, just behind the leader. This ensures that they will not have to chase after the rest of the group. This positioning also allows them to be watched from behind by more experienced riders.

questions.question: To be effective, eye or face shield protection must be all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Too tight to allow sunglasses or eyeglasses to be worn.
questions.answerC: Free of scratches.
questions.answerD: Able to allow clear views to both sides.
questions.explanation: To be effective, an eye or face shield must be free of scratches; be resistant to penetration; allow clear views to both sides; fasten securely; permit air to pass through to prevent fogging; and allow room for eyeglasses or sunglasses, if needed.

questions.question: If it is warm outside, should you wear a leather jacket while riding?
questions.answerA: No, it will make you too hot.
questions.answerB: Yes, but take frequent breaks to remove the jacket and cool off.
questions.answerC: Yes, riding jackets are made to keep the rider cool, even in warm weather.
questions.answerD: No, jackets get in the way of steering.
questions.explanation: In warm weather, a riding jacket will help prevent dehydration in addition to serving the basic protective function that it provides at all times. Many jackets are designed to protect riders against overheating, even in warm weather.

questions.question: How is the accelerator controlled?
questions.answerC: With the right foot
questions.answerD: With the left foot
questions.explanation: The accelerator of a motorcycle is located by the right handgrip and is controlled with the right hand.

questions.question: When riding near stopped or slow-moving cars, a motorcyclist should:
questions.answerA: Pull over and wait until traffic begins to move.
questions.answerB: Ride on the shoulder to get through the area as quickly as possible.
questions.answerC: Weave between the cars to get through the area as quickly as possible.
questions.answerD: Not weave between the cars.
questions.explanation: Riding between slowed or parked cars can leave you vulnerable to unexpected hazards, such as opening car doors or cars suddenly pulling into traffic. If a hazard arises, you will not have room to safely maneuver. Never travel on the shoulder of a road because other drivers will never expect you to be there.

questions.question: To be effective, an eye or face shield must:
questions.answerC: Not allow for eyeglasses to fit underneath.
questions.answerD: Restrict your vision to the sides.
questions.explanation: To be effective, an eye or face shield must be free of scratches; be resistant to penetration; allow clear views to both sides; fasten securely; permit air to pass through to prevent fogging; and allow room for eyeglasses or sunglasses, if needed.

questions.question: A motorcycle with a sidecar:
questions.answerB: Can tip over if making a turn too fast.
questions.answerC: Is designed to take corners at any speed.
questions.answerD: Should not be used for loading items.
questions.explanation: Even with three wheels on the ground, a sidecar can tip over if it is being turned too sharply or is moving too fast for a corner.

questions.question: When changing lanes, riders should:
questions.answerA: Rely only on their mirrors to identify other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Turn their head to look for traffic behind them.
questions.answerC: Not worry about other traffic.
questions.answerD: Slam on the brakes to allow any vehicles in their blind spot to pass.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle has blind spots just like any other vehicle. A rider must always turn their head to check for traffic before changing lanes.

questions.question: A person who is above the legal drinking age with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of ______ is considered legally intoxicated.
questions.answerC: 0.06 percent
questions.answerD: 0.08 percent
questions.explanation: For people of legal drinking age, a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher is considered legally intoxicated. It is both illegal and dangerous to ride a motorcycle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: When a vehicle attempts to pass you from behind, you should:
questions.answerA: Move to the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Move to the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Move to the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Not be concerned about which portion of the lane you are using.
questions.explanation: When being passed, it is generally best to ride in the center portion of your lane. Being too close to the passing vehicle increases the risk of a collision.

questions.question: When preparing to pass another vehicle on the left, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Get as close as possible to the vehicle in front of you.
questions.answerD: Not signal your intentions, as that may distract the driver you are passing.
questions.explanation: When passing another vehicle on the left, you should ride in the left portion of your lane. Signal your intentions and check for traffic. Pass when it is safe to do so, then signal and return to your original lane when traffic allows.

questions.question: Which fabric provides the best protection for motorcycle riders?
questions.answerC: Wool
questions.answerD: Polyester
questions.explanation: Jackets and pants made of leather offer the greatest degree of protection to those riding motorcycles.

questions.question: Maximum front-line braking is accomplished by:
questions.answerC: Using both brakes.
questions.answerD: Using the rear brake while downshifting.
questions.explanation: Maximum straight-line braking is accomplished by fully applying both the front and rear brakes without locking either wheel. You should always use both brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: You’ll have a better chance of avoiding serious injury if you wear all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Ear buds.
questions.answerD: Protective clothing.
questions.explanation: To protect yourself against injury, you should wear a DOT-compliant helmet; face or eye protection; a jacket and long pants made of sturdy material; boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles; and gloves made of durable material.

questions.question: When riding at night, you should travel:
questions.answerA: More slowly than you would during the day under similar conditions.
questions.answerB: At the speed you would travel during the day under similar conditions.
questions.answerC: Faster than you would during the day under similar conditions.
questions.answerD: On the shoulder of the road so other vehicles can see you.
questions.explanation: When riding at night, travel at a slower speed than you would during the day under similar weather and traffic conditions. It can be difficult to see potential hazards in the dark, so slowing down can increase your chances of avoiding any hazards.

questions.question: Most motorcycles have rounded, or convex, mirrors. These mirrors:
questions.answerA: Are easy to get used to right away.
questions.answerB: Make cars seem closer than they actually are.
questions.answerC: Provide a narrow view of the road.
questions.answerD: Make cars seem farther away than they actually are.
questions.explanation: In comparison to flat mirrors, convex mirrors provide a wider view of the road behind you. They also make objects seem farther away than they actually are. You should practice judging distances in convex mirrors if you are not used to them.

questions.question: In which of the following situations should you increase your following distance?
questions.answerC: You are able to see the roadway through vehicles in front of you.
questions.answerD: There is pleasant and clear weather.
questions.explanation: While a two-second following distance is generally adequate, you should increase your following distance any time conditions would require a longer stopping distance, such as when the pavement is slippery due to poor weather conditions. Additionally, you should increase your following distance at night, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead, and when traffic is heavy.

questions.question: When going through a curve, you should:
questions.answerA: Always stay in the same portion of the lane throughout the entire curve.
questions.answerB: Always stay in the left portion of the lane throughout the entire curve.
questions.answerC: Always stay in the right portion of the lane throughout the entire curve.
questions.answerD: Remember that the best path may not follow the curve of the road.
questions.explanation: Road and traffic conditions can change at any time. Always be prepared to change your lane position as appropriate no matter where you are on a roadway. The best path through a curve does not necessarily follow the curve of the road.

questions.question: Can clothing help prevent injuries in the event of a crash?
questions.answerA: No, clothing is not really for protection.
questions.answerB: No, clothing is more of a personal choice.
questions.answerC: Yes, but only if garments are very loose and flap in the wind.
questions.answerD: Yes, if pants and a jacket cover your arms and legs completely.
questions.explanation: Appropriate clothing can reduce the risk of injury in a crash. Choose a jacket and pants that cover your arms and legs, are made of sturdy material, and are snug enough that they do not flap in the wind.

questions.question: When riding at night, how should your following distance compare to your following distance during the day?
questions.answerA: You should allow a longer following distance when following another vehicle at night.
questions.answerB: You should allow a shorter following distance when following another vehicle at night.
questions.answerC: You should always maintain the same following distance regardless of the time of day.
questions.answerD: Following distance really doesn’t matter.
questions.explanation: Distances are difficult to judge in the dark because visual cues (like shadows and light contrasts) can be missing or distorted. You should allow a longer following distance when riding at night than you do when riding during the day.

questions.question: The front brake supplies approximately how much of a motorcycle's potential stopping power?
questions.answerC: About 70 percent
questions.answerD: About 95 percent
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake. The front brake supplies at least 70 percent of a motorcycle's total stopping power.

questions.question: To increase your chances of being seen at an intersection, you should:
questions.answerC: Try to make eye contact with other drivers.
questions.answerD: Ride as closely as possible to the vehicle ahead.
questions.explanation: The single most important thing you can do to help others see you at an intersection is to ride with your headlight on. Your headlight should be on whenever your motorcycle is running.

questions.question: When riding, a cushion of space is helpful to:
questions.answerA: Give you space to react to hazards.
questions.answerC: Prevent you from avoiding hazards.
questions.answerD: Allow you to look at road signs.
questions.explanation: Allowing a cushion of space around your motorcycle at all times will help ensure that you will have time to react if another driver makes a mistake. You will need the space to maneuver safely.

questions.question: For the best protection, jackets and pants:
questions.answerA: Should cover your arms and legs completely.
questions.answerB: Should be loose and flap in the wind while you are riding.
questions.answerC: Should only partially cover your arms and legs.
questions.answerD: Should be made of wool.
questions.explanation: To provide adequate protection when riding, jackets and pants should cover your arms and legs completely. Your clothing should fit snugly but be loose enough to let you move freely. Leather or newer kinds of synthetic materials provide the best protection in the case of an accident.

questions.question: You will ______ hear a tire going flat.
questions.answerC: Frequently
questions.answerD: Seldom
questions.explanation: Motorcyclists will seldom hear their tire go flat. Tire failure is more commonly indicated by a sudden change in handling.

questions.question: Studies show that most crash-involved riders:
questions.answerA: Under-brake the front tire and over-break the rear tire.
questions.answerB: Over-break the front tire and under-brake the rear tire.
questions.answerC: Only use the front brake.
questions.answerD: Only use the rear brake.
questions.explanation: Most riders involved in crashes under-brake the front tire and over-brake the rear.

questions.question: The front brake:
questions.answerA: Should only be used when you need to stop quickly.
questions.answerB: Should be used only under slippery conditions.
questions.answerC: Is not as effective as the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Is safe to use, if used properly.
questions.explanation: Always use both brakes any time you slow or stop. It is safe to use the front brake, which is more powerful than the rear brake, as long as you use it properly.

questions.question: If your front tire goes flat while you are riding:
questions.answerC: There will be no change in the steering.
questions.answerD: The ride will feel too smooth.
questions.explanation: If the front tire of a motorcycle fails, it will cause the steering to feel heavy. If your steering feels heavy, immediately exit the road and inspect your tires.

questions.question: A motorcyclist should:
questions.answerA: Pick a favorite portion of the lane and stay in that portion all the time.
questions.answerB: Continually weave among the lane positions to keep other drivers out of their lane.
questions.answerC: Choose a lane position based on road and traffic conditions.
questions.answerD: Not worry about lane position.
questions.explanation: There is no one lane position that is always best and no one lane position that should always be avoided. Adjust your lane position in response to changes in road and traffic conditions.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle:
questions.answerA: You must complete the pass without exceeding the speed limit.
questions.answerB: You may complete the pass in a no passing zone if the pass was started before the no passing zone began.
questions.answerC: You may exceed the speed limit.
questions.answerD: You should pass on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: All passes must be completed within the posted speed limits and only in areas where passing is permitted.

questions.question: To receive maximum protection, wear a helmet that is certified by the:
questions.answerC: Federal Transportation Network.
questions.answerD: National Association of Helmets.
questions.explanation: To get maximum protection, use a motorcycle helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) standards.

questions.question: The best lane position:
questions.answerA: Is always the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Is always the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Is always the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Varies based on road, weather, and traffic conditions.
questions.explanation: There is no single lane position that is always best and no single lane position that should always be avoided. You should vary your lane position in response to changes in riding conditions.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerB: Keep your intentions unknown from other drivers.
questions.answerC: Always stay within a foot of another vehicle.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of being involved in a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: A helmeted rider is _______ more likely to survive a crash than a rider not wearing a helmet.
questions.answerC: Six times
questions.answerD: 20 times
questions.explanation: No matter the speed, riders who are not wearing helmets are three times more likely to die from head injuries than riders who are wearing helmets at the time of a crash.

questions.question: When preparing to pass another vehicle on the left, you should ride in:
questions.answerA: The left side of the lane.
questions.answerC: The right side of the lane.
questions.answerD: Either the right or center portions of the lane.
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass another vehicle on the left, you should ride in the left portion of your lane. This lane position will provide you with the most effective view of the passing lane.

questions.question: If you are riding over rain grooves or bridge gratings and your motorcycle begins to weave, you should:
questions.answerC: Relax, maintain a steady speed, and ride straight across the grooves.
questions.answerD: Move to the leftmost portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle may weave while riding over rain grooves or bridge gratings, but this is generally not dangerous. If your motorcycle begins to weave, simply relax and proceed straight ahead at a steady speed. Trying to ride in a zigzag pattern to compensate for the weave will only increase the hazard.

questions.question: You should do all of the following to lesson your chances of being in a crash, except:
questions.answerA: Be visible by wearing proper clothing and using your headlight.
questions.answerB: Communicate your intentions by using your turn signals and brake light.
questions.answerC: Search for hazards in your path.
questions.answerD: Hope the other drivers see you.
questions.explanation: To minimize your risk of a crash, ensure that you are visible to other drivers, communicating your intentions to other drivers, and maintaining a cushion of space around you. You should search for, identify, and separate hazards. Be prepared to react to anything that happens.

questions.question: Slippery surfaces can make it difficult to control a motorcycle. Which of the following would be considered a slippery surface?
questions.answerC: Dry pavement
questions.answerD: A parking lot
questions.explanation: Wet pavement; roads covered in loose gravel or sand; muddy, snowy, or icy areas; painted lane markings; and metal covers and plates in the road can be slippery surfaces. Motorcyclists should ride with extra caution when riding over slippery surfaces.

questions.question: If you are being chased by a dog, you should:
questions.answerB: Stop until the animal loses interest.
questions.answerC: Swerve around the animal.
questions.answerD: Approach the animal slowly, then speed up.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles often seem to attract dogs. If you are being chased by a dog, downshift and approach it slowly. Then, as you approach the dog, accelerate and leave it behind.

questions.question: If a friend has been drinking and wants to ride their motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerB: Encourage them to take less-crowded roads.
questions.answerC: Push their bike over.
questions.answerD: Encourage friends to talk them out of riding.
questions.explanation: Never let someone ride if they have had too much to drink. Do whatever you can to prevent them from riding. It can be helpful to recruit a group of friends to intervene and apply peer pressure to the person.

questions.question: Increase your following distance if:
questions.answerC: The roadway is wet.
questions.answerD: You can see through the vehicle in front of you.
questions.explanation: Open up your following distance if your motorcycle will require a longer distance than normal to stop. Additionally, if you are riding in heavy traffic or if you cannot see through the vehicle in front of you, you should also increase your following distance.

questions.question: The only way to rid your body of alcohol is through:
questions.answerC: Exercising.
questions.answerD: Taking a cold shower.
questions.explanation: The only way to remove the alcoholic content of a drink from your body is to allow your body time to eliminate it. There are no shortcuts to sobering up.

questions.question: An approved helmet:
questions.answerA: Allows the wearer to see as far to the sides as is necessary for safe riding.
questions.answerC: Does not have a chin strap.
questions.answerD: Protects the wearer's hearing.
questions.explanation: While some people believe that a helmet will limit their vision, this is not the case. Any U.S. Department of Transportation-approved helmet will allow the wearer to see as far as is needed for safe riding.

questions.question: When riding at night, a motorcyclist should maintain a minimum following distance of:
questions.answerC: Four seconds.
questions.answerD: Five seconds.
questions.explanation: Because it is more difficult to see and judge distances in the dark than in daylight, you should maintain an expanded following distance of at least three seconds when riding at night. It may take you longer than usual to realize the vehicle in front of you has stopped and you may need additional time to slow or stop to avoid hitting the vehicle.

questions.question: Which of the following is not important when looking for a motorcycle helmet?
questions.answerA: The helmet meets U.S. Department of Transportation standards.
questions.answerB: The helmet fits snugly all the way around your head.
questions.answerC: The helmet has no obvious defects, such as cracks or loose padding.
questions.answerD: The helmet looks cool.
questions.explanation: To ensure that a helmet will provide you with as much protection as possible, check to see if it meets U.S. DOT and state standards; fits snugly all the way around your head; and has no obvious defects, such as cracks, loose padding, or frayed straps.

questions.question: What does this hand signal mean?
questions.answerC: Right turn
questions.answerD: Backing up
questions.explanation: Instead of or in addition to mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is bent at the elbow and pointing upward, it means the operator plans to turn right or change lanes to the right.

questions.question: What can help reduce the risk of a head or neck injury in the event of a crash?
questions.answerC: Wearing a helmet
questions.answerD: Not allowing a passenger on the motorcycle
questions.explanation: Wearing a helmet is the single most effective thing you can do to reduce the risk of head or neck injuries in the event of a crash.

questions.question: Many over-the-counter drugs:
questions.answerC: Only affect your riding if you drink along with taking the medication.
questions.answerD: Have the same effect on everyone.
questions.explanation: Like alcohol, many other drugs (including prescription medications, over-the-counter medications, and illegal drugs) have side effects that may impair your ability to ride safely.

questions.question: Taking a turn too fast:
questions.answerA: Is acceptable as long as you stay under the speed limit.
questions.answerB: Is safer on a motorcycle than in a car.
questions.answerC: Is acceptable as long as no vehicles are near you.
questions.answerD: Can cause you to end up in another lane or leave the road.
questions.explanation: Taking a turn too fast is dangerous. If you cannot hold the turn, you may end up turning into another lane or even off of the road entirely. Use caution when taking a turn.

questions.question: Smoothly downshifting on motorcycles:
questions.answerB: Can allow the rider to engine brake.
questions.answerC: Is illegal.
questions.answerD: Should not be done if other vehicles are around.
questions.explanation: Engine braking by smoothly downshifting can be a useful option for motorcyclists. If you choose to engine brake, apply your brake lights separately to let other drivers know that you are slowing down.

questions.question: What should you do to maintain proper control of your motorcycle while turning?
questions.answerA: Increase your speed before entering the turn.
questions.answerC: Look through the turn to anticipate the best course of action.
questions.answerD: Come to a complete stop before entering the turn.
questions.explanation: To maintain directional control through a turn, you should look through the turn by turning only your head. Slow down before turning and lean your motorcycle in the appropriate direction.

questions.question: Your lane position should:
questions.answerA: Protect your lane from other drivers.
questions.answerB: Allow you a nice view of scenery.
questions.answerC: Place you in other drivers’ blind spots.
questions.answerD: Hide your intentions from other drivers.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position can optimize a number of safety factors. Your lane position should keep you out of other vehicles’ blind spots, increase your ability to see and be seen, help you avoid surface hazards, help you avoid wind blasts from other vehicles, and provide you with an escape route from any hazards that might arise. You should be positioned in a way that discourages other drivers from trying to share your lane.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Always pick one part of the lane to occupy and never leave that part of the lane.
questions.answerB: Vary your lane position as conditions warrant.
questions.answerC: Only ride in the center of the lane so other vehicles can see you more easily.
questions.answerD: Ride in a zigzag pattern so other drivers notice you.
questions.explanation: There is no one lane position that is always best, nor one that should always be avoided. Change your lane position as necessary based on changing road and traffic conditions.

questions.question: Mirror checks:
questions.answerB: Should only be done on long trips.
questions.answerC: Should be part of your normal scanning routine.
questions.answerD: Are not helpful since you can’t do anything about what is behind you.
questions.explanation: Frequent mirror checks should be part of your normal searching routine. Additionally, make a special point of using your mirrors before changing lanes, when stopping at an intersection, and before slowing down.

questions.question: More than half of all crashes:
questions.answerA: Occur at speeds greater than 35 mph.
questions.answerC: Happen in the dark.
questions.answerD: Involve riders who have little experience on their motorcycles.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes involve riders with little experience on their motorcycle.

questions.question: In a normal turn:
questions.answerA: The motorcycle and rider should lean together.
questions.answerB: The motorcycle and rider should lean in opposite directions.
questions.answerC: The motorcycle should lean, but the rider should not.
questions.answerD: The rider should lean, but the motorcycle should not.
questions.explanation: During normal turns, the motorcycle and the rider should be leaning together at the same angle. In slow, tight turns, only the motorcycle should lean while the rider keeps their body straight up.

questions.question: During the day, your headlight should:
questions.answerB: Be used on its high beam setting.
questions.answerC: Be used on its low beam setting.
questions.answerD: Alternate between high beam and low beam settings.
questions.explanation: Using your high beam headlight during the day increases the likelihood that other drivers will see you. Use your high beam headlight any time you are not riding behind or approaching other vehicles.

questions.question: Since most crashes happen during daylight hours, you should:
questions.answerB: Wear bright clothing all the time.
questions.answerC: Ride on the shoulder and stay out of traffic.
questions.answerD: Wear dark clothing all the time.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes happen in broad daylight. You should always wear brightly-colored clothing when riding to maximize your chances of being seen, even during the day.

questions.question: The shortest and safest stops are accomplished:
questions.answerA: By using only the rear brake.
questions.answerB: By using only the front brake.
questions.answerC: By allowing the front tire to lock up.
questions.answerD: By using both the front and rear brakes.
questions.explanation: The shortest and safest stops are achieved by using both the front and rear brakes in a smooth and progressive manner, without skidding either tire.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection should be done:
questions.answerC: Once a month.
questions.answerD: Twice a month.
questions.explanation: Perform an inspection of your motorcycle before every ride. This takes only a few minutes and helps prevent dangerous situations before entering traffic.

questions.question: When riding on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerC: Move to the edge of the road.
questions.answerD: Ride in the tire tracks left by cars.
questions.explanation: Strategies for safe riding on slippery surfaces include reducing your speed, avoiding sudden moves, staying away from the edge of the road, and riding in the tire tracks left by other cars.

questions.question: A good way to handle tailgaters is to:
questions.answerA: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerC: Use your horn and make obscene gestures.
questions.answerD: Speed up to put distance between you and the tailgater.
questions.explanation: The best way to handle a tailgater is to change lanes and let them pass you. Speeding up may cause them to tailgate you at a higher speed, only increasing the danger.

questions.question: If you are being chased by a dog, you should:
questions.answerB: Stop until the animal loses interest.
questions.answerC: Swerve around the animal.
questions.answerD: Approach the animal slowly, then speed up.
questions.explanation: If a dog is chasing your motorcycle, downshift and slowly approach the dog. Once you have gotten close to the animal, accelerate and leave it behind. Do not attempt to kick it.

questions.question: Rain suits:
questions.answerC: Are not needed since motorcycles shouldn't be operated in the rain.
questions.answerD: Should tear easily.
questions.explanation: High-quality rain suits designed for motorcycle riding will resist tearing and ballooning when a rider travels at high speeds.

questions.question: When applying the front brake, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the lever by squeezing firmly and progressively.
questions.answerB: Grab at the brake with only two fingers.
questions.answerC: Press down on the brake lever with your foot.
questions.answerD: Stomp on the brake lever.
questions.explanation: To apply the front brake, firmly and smoothly squeeze the brake lever with all four fingers, applying progressively more force.

questions.question: As you slow or stop, you should:
questions.answerC: Take the bike out of gear.
questions.answerD: Stay in the same gear.
questions.explanation: You should shift down through the gears with the clutch as you slow or stop. Stay in first gear while you are stopped so you can move quickly, if needed.

questions.question: A passenger on a motorcycle should:
questions.answerA: Mount the motorcycle before the engine starts.
questions.answerB: Mount the motorcycle after the engine starts.
questions.answerC: Sit as close to the rear of the motorcycle as possible.
questions.answerD: Hold onto the seat.
questions.explanation: Passengers should get on a motorcycle only after the engine has been started and the transmission is put in neutral. They should sit as far forward as possible without hindering the operator's control of the motorcycle and should hold onto the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: When traveling on a motorcycle with a sidecar, the passenger should ride:
questions.answerC: Either on the motorcycle or in the sidecar.
questions.answerD: Neither on the motorcycle or in the sidecar.
questions.explanation: If your motorcycle has a sidecar, it is best for your passenger to ride in the sidecar. They should keep their hands inside the sidecar at all times.

questions.question: A face shield should:
questions.answerA: Allow a clear view to both sides.
questions.answerB: Prevent air from passing through it.
questions.answerC: Be tight enough to prevent glasses from fitting underneath it.
questions.answerD: Should not fasten too tightly.
questions.explanation: To be effective, a face shield must be free of scratches; be resistant to penetration; allow clear views to both sides; fasten securely; permit air to pass through; and permit enough room for eyeglasses or sunglasses, if needed.

questions.question: When being followed too closely by another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerC: Allow the other driver to pass you.
questions.answerD: Exit the roadway.
questions.explanation: The best way to deal with a tailgater is to get them ahead of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Speeding up may only increase the danger by encouraging them to continue tailgating you at a higher speed.

questions.question: When riding at night you should:
questions.answerC: Use the vehicle in front of you to help see.
questions.answerD: Wear tinted glasses.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision when riding at night, be sure to reduce your speed and increase your following distance. Use the headlights of vehicles ahead of you to see farther down the road. You should always be flexible about your lane position, especially when riding at night.

questions.question: If your motorcycle begins to weave while you are riding over rain grooves or bridge gratings, you should:
questions.answerA: Relax, maintain a steady speed, and ride straight across the surface.
questions.answerB: Tighten your hold on the handle grips and increase your speed to get past the hazard.
questions.answerC: Travel in a zigzag motion.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder instead of on the grooves.
questions.explanation: The weaving motion that occurs when a motorcycle rides over rain grooves or bridge gratings is generally not dangerous. If you experience weaving when riding over one of these surfaces, simply relax and proceed straight across the grooves or gratings at a steady speed. Trying to compensate for the weaving motion by zigzagging is more dangerous than riding straight.

questions.question: What may help if you experience slippage of your drive chain?
questions.answerC: Using the throttle more
questions.answerD: Applying the rear brake
questions.explanation: If you experience chain slippage, tightening the chain may help. If tightening the chain does not reverse the problem, replace the chain before continuing to ride your motorcycle.

questions.question: How can you regain control if your rear tire locks up?
questions.answerC: Swerve the bike in the direction with the fewest hazards.
questions.answerD: With the brake engaged, try to accelerate.
questions.explanation: To regain control of a locked rear wheel, the brake must be released. However, if you accidentally lock the rear brake on a good traction surface, you can keep it locked until you have completely stopped.

questions.question: Do not change gears on railroad tracks because:
questions.answerC: Other drivers may not be expecting you to change gears.
questions.answerD: The uneven surface may make it more difficult to switch gears.
questions.explanation: It is best not to shift gears when crossing railroad tracks. There is a chance your motorcycle might stall while you are on the tracks.

questions.question: Riding directly alongside another vehicle is:
questions.answerB: Encouraged to allow other drivers to see you better.
questions.answerC: Discouraged because you may be in the other vehicle’s blind spot.
questions.answerD: Discouraged because the other vehicle may think you are trying to race.
questions.explanation: Riding directly alongside another vehicle is dangerous both because you may be in the vehicle's blind spot, and because the vehicle may block your route of escape from additional hazards.

questions.question: Once a motorcycle helmet has been involved in a crash, it should be:
questions.answerC: Sold to another rider.
questions.answerD: Outfitted with a new chinstrap.
questions.explanation: Replace any helmet that has been worn during a crash.

questions.question: When approaching railroad tracks that cross your lane at an angle, it is usually:
questions.answerA: Safest to ride straight within your lane to cross the tracks.
questions.answerB: Dangerous to ride straight within your lane to cross the tracks.
questions.answerC: Not safe to cross tracks on a motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Safest to cross the tracks by riding on the shoulder of the road.
questions.explanation: When approaching railroad tracks that cross your lane at an angle, it is best to simply cross the tracks while riding straight within your lane. Turning to cross the tracks at a 90-degree angle could be dangerous because you could end up crossing into another lane of traffic.

questions.question: When someone follows you too closely, you should:
questions.answerB: Not worry about them and just focus on the road in front of you.
questions.answerC: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder and let them pass.
questions.explanation: The best way to handle a tailgater is to change lanes and let them pass you. Speeding up may cause them to tailgate you at a higher speed, only increasing the danger. Never ride on the shoulder of a road because drivers will never expect you to be there and may leave the road suddenly.

questions.question: When entering a curve, a group should:
questions.answerC: Ride in pairs.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: While riding in a staggered formation is usually best, a group should switch into a single-file formation when turning, taking curves, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: A motorcyclist is well-protected if they are wearing:
questions.answerA: A jacket that allows the arms to be exposed.
questions.answerC: Leather gloves.
questions.answerD: Shoes that stop below their ankle.
questions.explanation: For your protection while riding, it is best to wear a jacket and pants that cover your arms and legs completely. Boots or shoes should be tall and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles. Footwear should have low heels that will not catch on the foot pegs or rough road surfaces. Gloves made of leather or another durable material will help protect your hands in the event of a crash while providing you with an improved grip on the controls.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a slippery surface?
questions.answerB: A strip of oil in the center of a lane
questions.answerC: Mud on pavement
questions.answerD: Dry pavement
questions.explanation: A number of surfaces can provide poor traction for tires. Wet pavement; roads covered in loose gravel or sand; muddy, snowy, or icy areas; painted lane markings; oily areas; and metal covers and plates in the road can be more hazardous for a motorcyclist than dry pavement.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in an accident, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride within a foot of the vehicle in front of you.
questions.answerC: Signal only when you feel like it.
questions.answerD: Stay alert and be prepared to act to avoid a crash.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: The human body rids itself of about one alcoholic drink per hour. If a person consumes seven drinks in three hours, how many drinks likely remain in that person’s system three hours after their final drink?
questions.answerC: Four
questions.answerD: Five
questions.explanation: The minimum number of drinks remaining in a person's system can be estimated by subtracting the number of hours since their last drink from the total number of drinks consumed. For example: a person who has consumed seven drinks in three hours would have a minimum of four drinks remaining in their system three hours later.

questions.question: To stop quickly, you should:
questions.answerC: Use both brakes.
questions.answerD: Use the rear brake firmly while gradually increasing the braking pressure of the front brake.
questions.explanation: To stop quickly, apply both brakes at the same time.

questions.question: Riding gloves are often:
questions.answerC: Not pre-curved.
questions.answerD: Unsafe for the rider.
questions.explanation: Gloves designed for motorcycle riding are usually made of leather. In addition to improving your grip, gloves provide protection for a rider's hands and fingers.

questions.question: The single most effective thing you can do to improve your chances of surviving an accident is:
questions.answerC: Ask others about how to ride more safely.
questions.answerD: Watch training videos.
questions.explanation: The single most important measure you can take to reduce your risk of injury or death in the event of an accident is to wear a helmet.

questions.question: If you must stop quickly in a curve, you should:
questions.answerA: Straighten up, square the handlebars, and stop.
questions.answerB: Abruptly apply both brakes while leaning.
questions.answerC: Apply only the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Apply only the front brake.
questions.explanation: If you must stop quickly while in a curve, you should first straighten and square the handlebars, then stop. If straightening your motorcycle is not possible, you should apply the brakes smoothly and gradually, reduce your lean angle, then increase the brake pressure as you slow down.

questions.question: Making eye contact with another driver:
questions.answerA: Indicates that the driver sees you.
questions.answerB: Doesn’t mean that the driver will properly yield to you.
questions.answerC: Guarantees that the other driver will properly yield to you.
questions.answerD: May make the driver mad.
questions.explanation: Never rely on eye contact as an assurance that a driver will properly yield to you. It is common for drivers to look directly at motorcyclists and still fail to notice them.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a factor in determining blood alcohol content (BAC)?
questions.answerB: How fast the alcohol is consumed
questions.answerC: The drinker's body weight
questions.answerD: How often the drinker consumes alcohol
questions.explanation: The three major factors that affect a person's blood alcohol content (BAC) are the amount of alcohol consumed, how fast the alcohol was consumed, and the drinker's body weight. It is illegal and dangerous to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: Moose on the roadway are often difficult to see because:
questions.answerA: Most operators aren’t looking for moose.
questions.answerB: A moose’s eyes are above headlight level, so the light from the headlight isn’t reflected in their eyes.
questions.answerC: A moose has light-colored fur.
questions.answerD: A moose often blends in with the background.
questions.explanation: Moose on the roadway are often difficult to see, both because they have dark fur and because their eyes are higher than most vehicles' headlights. Unlike animals with eyes closer to the height of headlights, a moose's eyes will not reflect the light of headlights when a vehicle is approaching.

questions.question: Generally, the body eliminates one alcoholic drink per hour. If a person consumed eight alcoholic drinks four hours ago, how many drinks likely remain in their body?
questions.answerC: Three drinks
questions.answerD: Four drinks
questions.explanation: The minimum number of drinks left in a person's system can be estimated by subtracting the number of hours since the last drink from the total number of drinks consumed. In this case, the alcohol content of about four drinks would remain.

questions.question: To stop quickly, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Throttle down and use the front brake.
questions.answerC: Use the front brake only.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes at the same time.
questions.explanation: To stop quickly, apply both brakes at the same time.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume the passenger has traveled by motorcycle before.
questions.answerB: Not assume the passenger has traveled by motorcycle before and explain the process.
questions.answerC: Not let them ask questions.
questions.answerD: Not bother with explaining anything since they are only a passenger and not in control of the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle passenger needs to understand how to ensure a safe ride ride for both themselves and the operator. An operator should never assume the passenger already knows what to do. Give a passenger complete instructions before every ride.

questions.question: When riding in a group, the best way to keep ranks close while maintaining an adequate safety cushion is to ride:
questions.answerC: In a single-file line.
questions.answerD: In a passing formation.
questions.explanation: A staggered formation is the best way to keep ranks close while still maintaining an adequate space cushion for all riders. Ride in a single-file line when riding in curves, turning, or entering or leaving a highway. Never ride side-by-side with another rider.

questions.question: When braking, you should:
questions.answerA: Squeeze the front brake and press the rear brake.
questions.answerB: Grab at the front brake and squeeze the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Jam on the front brake and grab at the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Press down on the front brake and jam on the rear brake.
questions.explanation: To brake, squeeze the front brake lever and press down on the rear brake pedal. Always use both brakes when slowing or stopping.

questions.question: You should check your tires for all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: General wear.
questions.answerD: Flexibility.
questions.explanation: When doing a pre-ride inspection of your motorcycle, you should check the air pressure, general wear, and tread of your tires.

questions.question: The front brake:
questions.answerA: Provides less than half of a motorcycle's braking power.
questions.answerB: Provides about 70 percent of a motorcycle's braking power.
questions.answerC: Should not be used unless the roadway is wet.
questions.answerD: Should be the only brake you use.
questions.explanation: The front brake is much more powerful than the rear one and provides at least 70 percent of a motorcycle's total stopping power. Use both brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: The proper footwear for riding a motorcycle:
questions.answerC: Has tall heels.
questions.answerD: Is always sneakers.
questions.explanation: When riding, you should wear sturdy footwear that is high enough to cover and support your ankles. Short-heeled footwear is best because taller heels may catch on rough surfaces. Laces should be tucked in so that they can't be caught on anything.

questions.question: When you are being passed by a vehicle on your left, you should:
questions.answerA: Help the other driver by moving as far to the right as possible.
questions.answerB: Help the other driver by moving to the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Ride in the center portion of your lane.
questions.answerD: Ride in the left portion of your lane
questions.explanation: When being passed, it is best to ride in the center portion of your lane. Riding on the side nearest to the passing vehicle increases the risk of a collision. Riding on the side farthest from the passing vehicle is also dangerous because it may tempt them to merge back into your lane too soon. Stay in the center portion of the lane when being passed.

questions.question: What is often found in the center portion of the lane?
questions.answerC: Lane markings
questions.answerD: Ice
questions.explanation: Drippings from cars tend to form an oily strip in the center of each lane. Unless conditions are wet, it is usually still safe for a motorcycle to operate on the center strip.

questions.question: Successful motorcyclists know they are safest when they are:
questions.answerC: On the side of the road.
questions.answerD: In the left side of the lane.
questions.explanation: Successful motorcyclists know that they are safest when they are clearly seen by other road users. Use your headlight, brake light, signals, and lane position to maximize your visibility.

questions.question: Several factors influence blood alcohol concentration (BAC). Which of the following does not play a role?
questions.answerC: Body weight
questions.answerD: Height
questions.explanation: There are several major factors that can affect a person's blood alcohol concentration (BAC). A BAC is determined in part by the amount of alcohol someone has consumed, how fast they consumed the alcohol, and their body weight.

questions.question: Because of their small size, motorcycles seem to be:
questions.answerA: Traveling faster than they actually are.
questions.answerB: Traveling more slowly than they actually are.
questions.answerC: Not moving when they actually are.
questions.answerD: Closer than they actually are.
questions.explanation: Because of their size, motorcycles may seem to be traveling faster than they actually are.

questions.question: Normally, you should maintain a following distance of:
questions.answerC: Three seconds.
questions.answerD: Four seconds.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, you should allow at least two seconds of distance between you and the vehicle ahead of you. Increase your following distance any time conditions are less than ideal.

questions.question: When going through a turn on a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep your eyes focused close to the front of the motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Look through the turn to where you want to go.
questions.answerC: Turn your entire body to see through the turn.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed before the turn.
questions.explanation: When making a turn, you should look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn just your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: Helmeted riders are ________ more likely to survive than those not wearing helmets at the time of a crash.
questions.answerC: Eight times
questions.answerD: Ten times
questions.explanation: At any speed, wearing a helmet will make you three times more likely to survive head injuries in the event of a crash than you would if not wearing a helmet.

questions.question: Making eye contact with another driver:
questions.answerA: Guarantees that the other driver will properly yield to you.
questions.answerB: Is not worth the effort it takes.
questions.answerC: Doesn’t mean that the driver will properly yield to you.
questions.answerD: Means that the other driver knows you are there.
questions.explanation: You should never take eye contact with another driver as a guarantee that they will properly yield the right-of-way to you.

questions.question: Most motorcycles:
questions.answerC: Have brakes in both the front and rear.
questions.answerD: Have three brakes: one in the front, one in the rear, and an emergency brake.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles generally have two brakes, one for the front wheel and one for the rear wheel.

questions.question: Maintain an adequate following distance behind other vehicles:
questions.answerA: To allow you time and space to identify and react to hazards.
questions.answerC: To allow for traffic counters to accurately count you as a vehicle.
questions.answerD: To encourage other drivers to cut you off.
questions.explanation: Maintaining an adequate following distance ensures that you will have enough space to stop or swerve out of the way if the vehicle ahead of you stops suddenly. A space cushion also provides you with a better view of any hazards on the road surface, such as potholes.

questions.question: If you wait one hour to ride after having one alcoholic drink:
questions.answerA: You cannot be arrested for drinking and driving.
questions.answerB: Your riding skills will not be affected by the alcohol.
questions.answerC: Effects from the alcohol may still remain.
questions.answerD: You will be fine as long as you ride slowly.
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour. However, it is still possible for alcohol to accumulate in a person's system even if they consume only one drink per hour. This accumulation can still affect their ability to ride safely.

questions.question: On which of the following surfaces does a motorcycle have the best traction?
questions.answerC: Snow
questions.answerD: Leaves
questions.explanation: A number of surfaces can provide poor traction for tires. Wet pavement; roads covered in loose gravel or sand; muddy, snowy, or icy areas; painted lane markings; and metal covers and plates in the road can be more hazardous for a motorcyclist than dry pavement.

questions.question: When approaching an uneven surface, such as a bump or pothole, you should rise slightly off of your seat:
questions.answerA: So you can jump off the motorcycle if you need to.
questions.answerB: So your legs can absorb the shock.
questions.answerC: So other drivers can see you better.
questions.answerD: So you can get a better view of the uneven surface.
questions.explanation: When riding over an uneven surface, rising off of your seat will allow your joints to absorb some of the force of impact. This will make it less likely that the impact of the surface will throw you off of the motorcycle.

questions.question: The center portion of a lane usually contains an oily strip. This part of the lane is:
questions.answerB: Usually safe, unless the road is wet.
questions.answerC: Usually safe, unless it is sunny outside.
questions.answerD: Always safe, no matter the weather conditions.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars collect in a strip in the center of a traffic lane. Unless the road is wet, this area will generally still provide enough traction for motorcyclists to ride safely. Because the strip is usually no more than two feet wide, it is often possible to ride to one side of the strip and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: When riding in curves, turning, or entering a highway, the best group formation is:
questions.answerC: Staggered.
questions.answerD: Passing.
questions.explanation: While riding in a staggered formation is generally the best option when traveling in a group, riders should move into a single-file line through curves, through turns, and when entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: Shifting to a lower gear produces an effect similar to:
questions.answerC: Swerving.
questions.answerD: Turning.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycles have a manual transmission. Downshifting to a lower gear will slow you down.

questions.question: When being passed, all of the following are potential hazards, except:
questions.answerB: Objects being thrown from other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Blasts of wind.
questions.answerD: Headlights.
questions.explanation: When being passed, motorcyclists should be careful not to be hit by any part of the passing vehicle, including its mirrors. In addition to the vehicle itself, motorcyclists should be aware of wind gusts coming from the passing vehicle and potential objects being thrown by a passenger in the vehicle who may not be paying attention to the road.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection should:
questions.answerC: Be complicated to perform.
questions.answerD: Not be done before every ride.
questions.explanation: It is important to do a thorough inspection of your motorcycle before every ride. This will usually take you only a few minutes.

questions.question: Where is the greatest potential for conflict between a motorcycle and other traffic?
questions.answerC: Parking lots
questions.answerD: Residential areas
questions.explanation: The greatest potential for conflict between your motorcycle and other traffic is at intersections. Be extra alert when riding somewhere where another vehicle may cross in front of your path of travel.

questions.question: Before every ride, it is important to check all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: The lights.
questions.answerD: The seat fabric.
questions.explanation: Before every ride, you should complete a thorough check of your motorcycle. Be sure to check the rims and spokes to make sure none are bent, loose, or damaged; the condition and tread of the tires; and all of the lights.

questions.question: When passing a vehicle:
questions.answerA: You may exceed the speed limit until the pass is complete.
questions.answerB: You may disregard "No passing zone" markings if the pass was started in a passing zone.
questions.answerC: You may pass on the shoulder.
questions.answerD: You must complete the pass within the posted speed limits and within a legal passing zone.
questions.explanation: Passes must be completed within posted speed limits. Only pass where it is safe and legal to do so.

questions.question: A proper lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerC: Help you avoid traffic signals.
